captions.text:
Well, that's a Pikmin, Alph. You know...the
name on the box. Of course, I can't blame

you for not knowing. It's been nine years
since anybody's seen them. I've heard some

say it's because they blend in with their
environment. I've heard others say Nintendo

underutilizes any franchise that doesn't have
a plumber.

Hey, you say potato, I say Star Fox. Whatever
the case, they're back...popping up from the

ground like multicolored popcorn. And tiny
leaf by tiny leaf, they're sprouting new life

into Nintendo's barren platform. They're the
Pikmin, and they're a fitting reminder that,

even in the darkest, deadest places...there's
always signs of life.

And even though they've been in hibernation
for a decade, the Pikmin are still classic

Nintendo. The charm, the personality, but
most of all...because they take something

as daunting as a strategy game...and they
turn it into this incredibly warm and welcoming

experience. Something that's easy to understand.
Something anyone can play.

It's, like...Nintendo's really good at hiding
the medicine in the ice cream.

And they've never been more clever about it
than with Pikmin.

So yes, Pikmin 3 is a strategy game. It's
also the first Pikmin game without Captain

Olimar in a starring role. This time, we meet
three new explorers, brave travelers from

a distant world where food is scarce. And
hope scarcer yet. Forced to search the universe

for a good meal, they happen upon PNF-404...actually,
they crash upon it. Fortunately, they discover

an indigenous species that's willing to help
them out—the Pikmin.

As well as other species that aren't as willing
to help them out.
Now, the

foundation of Pikmin 3 is the same as its
predecessors. You control up to a hundred

Pikmin at once, and it's really a game about
delegation. You can split them into three

groups—each led by a different crew member—and
you can switch between them any time. Multitasking

is really important, but it can also be dangerous.
It's easy to lose track of your Pikmin, and

if you don't get them back to the ship by
nightfall...

They get...eaten alive. Because Mother Nature
is a heartless wench.
Who's apparently very big on punctuality.

Actually, that's one of the most interesting
things about Pikmin. It's built on this really

relaxed, kind of chill gameplay...but it creates
a ton of pressure, all because of the fear

of deadlines. And death. It such an effective
contrast, and it's really one of the game's

defining elements. Because there are so many
variables, Pikmin's exploration has a real

sense of danger, and that makes it exciting.
There's always a risk.
And there's always a consequence.

Speaking of consequences, Pikmin 3 brings
back some time limitations. See, in the original

Pikmin, you only had 30 in-game days to beat
it. In the sequel, there were no limitations.

This one combines the two approaches. So you
can take as long as you want, provided you

have enough food to last. Personally, I do
prefer Pikmin 2's openness, but Pikmin 3 strikes
a really satisfying balance.

And it gives your findings a real sense of
importance.

So with the time limitations, as well as the
addition of a third group...Pikmin 3 can definitely

feel a bit more hectic than the prior games.
I mean, you have those Pikmin harvesting berries,

you have these ones attacking that thing...and
where were those other ones? Obviously, staying

on top of everything can be really challenging,
but therein lies your strategy.

If you're losing Pikmin you can't even see,
you might need a new strategy.

You know what else you might need?! A new
Wii U game. Pikmin 3 is a new Wii U game.

It's also a great Wii U game. And it's a great
Nintendo game. With the problems they've been

having, it's easy to forget...what else Nintendo
has. It's easy to forget the Nintendo magic,

that little extra...something, that makes
a good Nintendo game so special.

And yeah, maybe it's a bad omen that a franchise
from their least-successful console is returning

on the Wii U, but forget what the Wii U could
be or doesn't have. What it has is Pikmin
3. And what Pikmin 3 has?
Is that little extra...something.

title: CGR Undertow - PIKMIN 3 review for Nintendo Wii U
